Description: Pancreatic cancer remains highly lethal, however recent insights regarding disease pathogenesis coupled with the emergence of new diagnostic methods and therapeutic agents engender a more hopeful outlook.  Here, we present distinctive features of PDAC that have emerged as causal aspects of this disease, and codify them as hallmarks such that sufficient attention can be focused on overcoming each for the benefit of patients. These seven common characteristics of pancreatic cancer include desmoplastic stroma, chronic inflammation, dysregulated metabolism, undruggable KRAS, early metastasis, rapid deconditioning and diagnostic deficiencies, and posit that these hallmarks are collectively responsible for disease aggressiveness and clinical failure. Finally, we propose a strategic framework to address these challenges and thereby improve patient outcomes.
